quoteFirst: For instance, in Chicago there is a system by which a subscriber, on connecting himself to a special circuit, is automatically informed of the correct time, by means of phonographs, between the hours of 8 a.m. and 10 p.m. New York goes further than this however, and has a regular system of news circulation by telephone. According to _Electricity_, the daily programme is as follows: “8 a.m., exact astronomical time;
quoteLast: , weather reports, London Stock Exchange news, special news item; 9 to 9.30 a.m., sales, amusements, business events; 9.45 to 10 a.m., personal news, small notices; 10 to 10.30 a.m., New York Stock Exchange and market news; 11.30 a.m. to 12 noon, local news, miscellaneous; 12 noon, exact astronomical time, latest telegrams, military and parliamentary news; 2 to 2.15 p.m., European cables; 1.15 to 2.30 p.m., Washington news; 2.30 to 2.45 p.m., fashions, ladies’ news; 2.45 to 3.15 p.m., sporting and theatrical news; 3.15 to 3.30 p.m., closing news from Wall
title: Electricity
author: McCormick, W. H. (William Henry), 1884-1952

quoteFirst: How long he sat there, sprawled disconsolately in the chair, alternately blaming himself for what had happened and then Arnold, hating Frank with a new and perfectly soul-filling hatred, I don’t know. But I do know that when a sense of the passage of time edged in past the varied and warring emotions and he looked at the tin clock on the bureau it was exactly
title: Guarding His Goal
author: Barbour, Ralph Henry, 1870-1944; Avison, George, 1885-1970 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: At
quoteLast: , as we had closed to within 20,000 yards of the rear ship, the Battle Cruisers manœuvred to keep on a line of bearing so that guns would bear, and _Lion_ fired a single shot, which fell short. The enemy at this time were in single line ahead, with Light Cruisers ahead and a large number of Destroyers on their starboard beam.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: At 8.15 A.M. the Battle Fleet was in Lat. 55.54 N., Long. 6.10 E., steering north at 17 knots, turning at
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916

quoteLast: , (Morning School,) from ten to twelve, (Middle School,) and from two till six P.M., (Evening School;) at the close of which prayers were read by the Præfect of School.
title: School-life at Winchester College
author: Mansfield, Robert Blachford, 1824-1908

quoteFirst: The pleasantest part of my day’s work used to be in the retirement of the Greek study and from
quoteTime: eight to nine in the morn
quoteLast: ing. Never a student of mine who did not come at that hour for some occasion or need. One man snatched the opportunity to read at sight a good part of the Odyssey. Another took up and discussed certain dialogues of Plato.
title: American Thumb-prints: Mettle of Our Men and Women
author: Stephens, Kate, 1853-1938

quoteFirst: At Nash, on 15th, eleven Cuckoos passed N.W. from 1 to 3 p.m., calm, mist. On 16th, five passed N.W. from
quoteLast: , light E.S.E. air, mist. On May 4th, four passed S.W. at 9 a.m., gentle E.S.E. breeze, mist, rain.

quoteFirst: From 1790 to 1833 Divinity students attended the lectures of the assistants to Archbishop King’s Lecturer (the Regius Professor had not at that time any assistants) on two days in the week, Tuesdays and Thursdays, from
quoteTime: eight to nine in the morn
quoteLast: ing. They were put through Burnet on the Thirty-nine Articles, and if any student attended three-fourths[99] of the lectures in each of the four terms of the Junior Bachelor year he received a certificate, which was inserted in the testimonium of his degree, and on this he was entitled to present himself for the Ordination Examination.
title: The Book of Trinity College Dublin 1591-1891
author: Trinity College (Dublin, Ireland)
